basics.name: Min-Geun Park
basics.label: Mechanical Engineer
basics.summary: A German-born theoretical physicist, widely ranked among the greatest and most influential scientists of all time

work.name: Advanced Intelligent Mechatronics Research Laboratory (AIMRL) - Georgia Tech
work.summary: In the Magnetic Leadscrew (ML) project, I enhanced system functionality by refining components, validated theoretical simulations through experiments, and modeled the ML using transfer functions. I also developed an Arduino-based control system to achieve precise position and force control.

work.name: Georgia Institute of Technology
work.summary: For the course ME4452 - Control Dynamic Systems, I conducted two-hour weekly office hours and delivered comprehensive review lectures, significantly aiding over 30 students in understanding complex concepts in control systems engineering. I received a 4.54/5 average in TA evaluations, with 100% of students endorsing me for future courses.

work.name: Samsung Electronics
work.summary: I evaluated the repeatability of a KUKA robot arm in compliance with ISO 9283 standards, using the Robot Operating System (ROS) and a Leica laser tracker for accurate measurements and detailed analysis.

work.name: Adaptive Robotic Manipulation (ARM) Laboratory - Georgia Tech
work.summary: I contributed to the development of an underactuated gripper using controllable stiffness joints. I developed a control system for adjusting air pressure in the joints to control their stiffness and created a test bed to analyze finger-object interaction, focusing on the impact of joint stiffness on dexterity. Additionally, I led a team of three students in project coordination, task delegation, and performance optimization to efficiently achieve project goals.

work.name: Samsung Electronics
work.summary: I developed a TensorFlow-based anomaly classification model for image data, achieving an impressive top-1 accuracy of 92%. Additionally, I conducted a comprehensive seminar on deep learning for team members interested in integrating AI into their research. The seminar covered fundamental AI concepts, effective training methodologies, and essential troubleshooting strategies, equipping my colleagues with the knowledge to leverage AI technologies effectively.

work.name: Robotics Lab - POSTECH
work.summary: Ieveloped a multisensory anomaly detection system for mobile robots in smart factories, employing RANSAC-Flow and f-AnoGAN algorithms to analyze the spatiotemporal context of thermal videos. The system, implemented using PyTorch, enhances the capabilities of mobile surveillance robots by efficiently detecting anomalies in dynamic factory environments.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
